qas.question: What does comparing the sequence alignment of genes' DNA measure?
What is the degree of sequence similarity between homologous genes called?
How do genes typically accumulate mutations over time?
Under what type of selection are genes constrained so they change more slowly?
What type of analyses can the sequence differences between genes be used for?

context: <a0_0>The relationship between genes<a0_0/> can be measured by comparing the sequence alignment of their DNA.:7.6 The degree of sequence similarity between homologous genes is called <a1_0>conserved sequence<a1_0/>. Most changes to a gene's sequence do not affect its function and so genes accumulate mutations over time <a2_0>by neutral molecular evolution<a2_0/>. Additionally, any selection on a gene will cause its sequence to diverge at a different rate. Genes under <a3_0>stabilizing<a3_0/> selection are constrained and so change more slowly whereas genes under directional selection change sequence more rapidly. The sequence differences between genes can be used for <a4_0>phylogenetic<a4_0/> analyses to study how those genes have evolved and how the organisms they come from are related.
